subject: Re: [junit] testing switch statements in method
msgSnippet: I m not sure if this helps for a constructor, but I use the PriviliegedAccessor class linked from the junit Faq to access private methods and fields in my
messageBody:
I'm not sure if this helps for a constructor, but I use the
PriviliegedAccessor class linked from the junit Faq to access private
methods and fields in my tests.

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/files/src/PrivilegedAccessor.java
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/files/src/PrivilegedAccessorTest.java

-Aaron

Kamal Ahmed wrote:

> Since this is an API, The contracts and design cannot change to suite
> junit,
> hence I cannot change the visibility
>
>
>
> _____
>
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
> Shane Mingins
> Sent: Sunday, March 05, 2006 6:27 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] testing switch statements in method
>
>
>
> On 3/6/06, Kamal Ahmed <KAhmed@...> wrote:
> >
> >
> > Any idea, Anyone on how to go about testing this? Because, When I am
> > trying
> > to use the TimePeriod constructor, I get an error:
> >
> > "Change the visibility of TimePeriod.java to public.
>
>
>
> So what happens when you change the constructor on TimePeriod to public?
>
> Cheers
> Shane
>
>
